answer_html: The probability of moving from location 3 to location 1 in 10 time steps is \(\displaystyle (P^{10})_{1,3} = 0.2875\)
answer_latex:
The probability of moving from location 3 to location 1 in 10 time steps
is $\displaystyle (P^{10})_{1,3} = 0.2875$
hints_html:
The probability of moving from location \(\displaystyle i\) to location \(\displaystyle j\) in \(\displaystyle k\) time steps is \(\displaystyle (P^k)_{j,i}\).

How does the fact that the walker is in location 3 after 10 days affect the question?

Given that the walker is in position 3 after 10 days, does it matter where he was coming from? How many steps does he take after day 10?

hints_raw:
The probability of moving from location <math> \displaystyle i </math> to location <math> \displaystyle j </math> in <math> \displaystyle k </math> time steps is <math> \displaystyle (P^k)_{j,i} </math>.
How does the fact that the walker is in location 3 after 10 days affect the question?
Given that the walker is in position 3 after 10 days, does it matter where he was coming from? How many steps does he take after day 10?
question: A 24
sols_html:
We are given that the walker is in location 3 when 10 days have passed and want to know the probability that the walker is in location 1 when 20 days have passed. This is identical to the situation if we are given that the walker is in location 3 when 0 days have passed and want to know the probability that the walker is in location 1 when 10 days have passed.

The probability of moving from location 3 to location 1 in 10 time steps is \(\displaystyle (P^{10})_{1,3} = 0.2875\)

We are given that the walker is in location 3 when 10 days have passed and want to know the probability that the walker is in location 1 when 20 days have passed. This is identical to the situation if we are given that the walker is in location 3 when 0 days have passed and want to know the probability that the walker is in location 1 when 10 days have passed.

The probability of moving from location 3 to location 1 in 10 time steps is <math> \displaystyle (P^{10})_{1,3} = 0.2875 </math>
statement_html:
Consider a random walk with three possible states and where the random walker (possibly) changes from state to state once every day according to the transition matrix P. Answer the following questions using the martix P and some of its powers given below.

\[\begin{aligned} P = \begin{bmatrix} 0.0284 & 0.5938 & 0.1626 \\ 0.9207 & 0.1579 & 0.1634 \\ 0.0509 & 0.2483 & 0.6740 \end{bmatrix} \\ P^{10} = \begin{bmatrix} 0.2832 & 0.2907 & 0.2875 \\ 0.3843 & 0.3753 & 0.3786 \\ 0.3325 & 0.3340 & 0.3339 \end{bmatrix} \\ P^{20} = \begin{bmatrix} 0.2874 & 0.2875 & 0.2875 \\ 0.3791 & 0.3790 & 0.3790 \\ 0.3335 & 0.3335 & 0.3335 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

What is the probability that a walker that is in location 3 when 10 days have passed from the beginning is in location 1 when 20 days have passed from the beginning?
